children.name: 3. Methodology: Physical variables and data-probes within the “shape your symptoms” workshop
Introduction
children.content:
The research introduces a method for collecting and communicating
healthcare data that draws on the exploratory potential of physicality.
Building on the theoretical foundations outlined in the previous
chapter, the following sections clarify how materials support the
association between symptoms and physical variables. The approach draws
inspiration from cultural probes for the elicitation of experience and
from data physicalization for the representational use of materials,
integrating these perspectives to foreground materiality as both a
medium for interaction and a tool for exploring the perception of
symptoms. A workshop serves as the practical enactment of this method.
The activity is designed to foster self-awareness and data literacy
among women affected by UTIs, expanding the expressive resources
available to describe the condition and supporting more informed
participation in diagnosis and treatment, including decisions related to
antibiotic use. This method aligns with ongoing shifts in healthcare
that emphasise more active patient involvement. By enabling individuals
to manage and communicate their health information, the approach
provides clinicians with richer and more contextual data to inform
clinical decisions.

children.name: 3.1 Physical variables for participatory data physicalization
Introduction
children.content:
This research introduces physical variables to capture and share the UTI
symptoms. Physical variables refer to material properties such as
texture, weight, shape, temperature, or movement that can be used to
represent sensations and states that are often difficult to verbalise.
Their use addresses a critical gap in healthcare data practices, where
subjective and specific aspects of illness frequently remain invisible.
By linking these material qualities to participants’ embodied
experiences, the research provides a means for symptoms to be
externalised in forms that others can perceive, interpret, and discuss.
This approach builds on insights from data physicalization, where
variables connect data to tangible forms, influencing how information is
felt, understood, and remembered. Within this study, physical variables
are used not only as design tools but as participatory devices that
allow individuals to explore, articulate, and negotiate their
experiences together.

The following chapter describes how the method is enacted through
workshops that use physical variables to transform personal perceptions
into forms of knowledge that others can recognise, interpret, and
discuss.

children.name: 3.1.1 Encoding and decoding multi-sensoriality
children.content:
Data physicalization expresses information through the material
properties of objects, using qualities such as colour, texture, weight,
temperature, or deformation as meaningful variations. These physical
variables act as deliberate material changes that encode information and
draw on the affordances of materials to shape how data is created,
encountered, and interpreted (Ranasinghe and Degbelo, 2023; Gwilt and
Davis in Gwilt, 2022). Engagement with these variables involves visual,
tactile, auditory, or kinetic senses, making meaning emerge through
coordinated, embodied interaction rather than through a single sensory
channel. This stands in contrast with traditional multimodal interfaces,
which often separate sensory inputs across distinct devices and
channels. Physicalizations instead support intermodal perception, where
senses reinforce each other and operate together, reflecting how
information is actually produced and perceived during material
interaction. For instance, auditory feedback can arise naturally when
textured surfaces are touched or manipulated, linking sound and touch
within the same experience (Barras, 2014). This integrated sensory
engagement underscores the distinction from conventional visualizations
that rely on fixed visual codes, positioning physicalizations as richer
and more situated encounters with data that expand the possibilities for
interpretation (Hornecker et al., 2023).

Within this context, the distinction between encoding and decoding
becomes a key consideration for understanding how meaning is produced.
Encoding involves structuring data through deliberate variations in
material properties, while decoding depends on how users perceive and
interpret these variations through their own sensibilities and embodied
engagement. This dynamic challenges the assumption that form carries a
stable and predetermined meaning. Instead, understanding develops
through active, situated interaction with materials. Physical variables
operate as multisensory units rather than isolated visual or haptic
cues, since qualities such as texture, weight, or sound are encountered
through whole-body involvement, including hand movement, posture, and
spatial orientation. Physical data representations therefore differ from
digital ones by grounding interpretation in direct, material contact.
This approach highlights interpretation as an embodied process in which
meaning forms through continuous engagement with objects and the sensory
feedback they provide.

children.name: 3.1.2 Variable classifications and roles
children.content:
The diversity and multisensory nature of physical variables have
inspired a range of classification approaches in data physicalization,
each reflecting distinct disciplinary priorities. One perspective
examines how variables behave during interaction, distinguishing between
passive geometric encodings that remain static and dynamic encodings
that respond to user input or environmental conditions (Dragicevic et
al., 2021). Other frameworks focus on the sensory organisation of
information, separating atomic variables that rely on a single sensory
dimension from composite variables that combine features such as
texture, shape, and arrangement to convey richer patterns (MacEachren,
1995). Further contributions draw on perceptual psychology to evaluate
how different properties support interpretation and memorability (Stusak
et al., 2016), or on design intention to differentiate conceptual
elements linked to purpose and aesthetics from practical elements
related to appearance and user experience (Dumičić et al., 2022).
Hornecker et al. (2023) add another layer by distinguishing explicit
variables that encode specific values, implicit properties that shape
perception without directly representing data, and consequential aspects
that emerge unintentionally during making. A complementary perspective
reframes physical variables as boundary objects capable of operating
across disciplines while accommodating diverse interpretations and uses
(Ranasinghe and Degbelo, 2023). This view highlights how the
multisensory qualities of materials can support expressive and
accessible data representations across fields such as Information
Visualization, Cartography, HCI, Sonification, Immersive Analytics, and
Neuroscience. Together, these perspectives position physical variables
not only as mechanisms for encoding data but also as connectors that
bridge disciplinary viewpoints and enable inclusive, contextually
grounded data practices.

children.name: 3.1.3 Do we need a vocabulary?
children.content:
Efforts to establish systematic approaches for understanding physical
variables have so far demonstrated how difficult it is to produce direct
one-to-one mappings between material properties and meanings.
Interpretation is shaped by cultural background, personal experience,
and the specific circumstances in which a physical artefact is produced
and encountered. This diversity challenges the possibility of designing
representations that are universally understood and underscores the need
for sensitivity to social and cultural factors. Iterative and
user-centred design processes become essential for supporting
interpretation within these varied conditions.

The absence of a shared vocabulary for describing physical design
elements creates additional challenges for the field of data
physicalization. Without consistent terminology, researchers and
practitioners struggle to build common understanding about encoding
mechanisms, analyse physicalizations systematically, and compare
projects across contexts (Hornecker et al., 2023). This gap limits
theoretical development by making it difficult to articulate
distinctions or build coherent frameworks. It also creates practical
obstacles for interdisciplinary communication, for translating theory
into design practice, and for establishing pedagogical structures for
teaching physicalization.

Perspectives on the need for standardisation remain divided. Some
researchers argue for a clearer vocabulary to support analytical clarity
and cumulative knowledge (Hornecker et al., 2023). Others, such as
Offenhuber (2023), view the current openness as a productive condition
that fosters creative exploration and accommodates diverse
representational approaches. This tension reflects a wider debate within
design research about how to balance theoretical rigour with
experimental and innovative practice. Rather than seeking to resolve
this tension, the present thesis treats physical variables as a flexible
structure that can support reflection, comparison, and discussion
without fixing a new communicative language. This perspective positions
the framework of variables as a generative tool: structured enough to
support enquiry, yet open enough to sustain creative potential.

children.name: 3.1.4 Positioning physical variables in symptom representation
children.content:
Existing classifications of physical variables tend to remain broad and
abstract, developed largely from theoretical considerations rather than
from sustained observation in applied contexts. Their generic nature
makes it difficult to determine how specific material properties convey
meaning in consistent ways across projects. Developing a more grounded
understanding requires research situated in well-defined contexts where
variables can be examined directly in use.

The present study addresses this need by analysing how physical
variables support the representation of UTI symptoms. Observing how
participants engage with materials to express their bodily perceptions
reveals patterns of meaning rooted in lived experience and directly
connected to the communication of health-related sensations. This
situated approach makes it possible to evaluate how particular variables
foster expression, whether participants tend to associate certain
properties with similar sensations, and how these associations
contribute to shared understanding during collective interpretation.

Findings generated through this work respond to the specific challenges
of symptom communication while also contributing to broader discussions
in data physicalization. Identifying and comparing patterns across
participants and sessions provides a foundation for more empirically
grounded accounts of how physical variables communicate meaning. This
process also clarifies whether these associations are entirely
context-dependent or whether some remain stable when applied across
different settings, supporting a more nuanced understanding of how
material properties function as representational tools.

Supporting meaningful use of physical variables in participatory
contexts requires materials that invite embodied interpretation and
enable explicit communication of subjective symptoms. To address this
requirement, the research draws together insights from cultural probes
and data physicalization. Cultural probes elicit personal, reflective,
and situated responses, while data physicalization provides tangible,
interpretable forms through which experience can be articulated.
Building on this complementarity, the study introduces data-probes as
tools specifically designed to prompt material engagement with embodied
signs and support the articulation of intimate, internal sensations.
Through this approach, the role of physical variables becomes closely
linked to sensory perception, co-creation, and the transformation of
subjective experience into forms that can be recognised and discussed by
others.

children.name: 3.2 Data-probes to elicit embodied interpretation
children.content:
This research formalises data-probes as a method that supports material
exploration for data collection, interpretation, and representation.
Data-probes are designed to prompt participants to engage directly with
physical materials, enabling embodied sensations to surface and become
communicable. Materiality plays a central role in this process. Through
touch, manipulation, and reflection, participants recognise aspects of
their symptoms and translate these perceptions into tangible forms that
can be shared and discussed.

The development of data-probes builds on the complementary insights of
cultural probes and data physicalization. From cultural probes they take
the capacity to elicit personal, reflective responses, yet they extend
this approach by encouraging active engagement rather than limiting
participation to individual observation or written feedback. The
emphasis on location in Gaver’s original probes is reinterpreted through
the lens of contemporary data practices and ethical considerations.
Traditional probes foregrounded physical localisation, using artefacts
such as maps or postcards to capture contextual insights in situations
where researchers could not be present (Gaver et al., 1999). While this
highlighted how lived experience relates to physical surroundings, it
treated context largely as a matter of place.

This research shifts the focus from localisation to situatedness,
drawing on Haraway’s view that knowledge is always produced within
specific social, cultural, and historical conditions (Haraway, 1988). In
this perspective, context is not defined by geographic coordinates but
by the lived conditions through which symptoms are perceived, expressed,
and interpreted. Data physicalization further contributes a
representational dimension, showing how materials can be configured,
manipulated, and reconfigured to embody and communicate experience.

By integrating these traditions, data-probes offer a method for
eliciting embodied interpretation through structured material
engagement. They provide participants with tools to articulate intimate
and subjective symptoms in ways that are grounded in lived experience
while remaining accessible for collective reflection.

Healthcare experiences, particularly in the case of UTIs, are shaped not
only by place but also by personal histories, cultural expectations, and
social dynamics. Data-probes are developed to generate data within this
wider notion of situatedness, ensuring that what emerges reflects the
complexity of embodied experience and remains grounded in the specific
conditions in which it is produced and discussed. Through this approach,
participants become active contributors of meaning, transforming
personally relevant insights into forms of knowledge with potential
clinical significance.

Alongside this emphasis on situatedness, the design of data-probes draws
on principles of data physicalization, particularly the idea that
materiality actively contributes to how knowledge is created and
interpreted. The literature shows how tangible artefacts invite
interaction, negotiation, and dialogue, with meaning emerging through
engagement rather than from their final form. Building on this
understanding, data-probes use physical materials not as static carriers
of information but as active elements in its generation.

During interaction with data-probes, participants select, manipulate,
and adapt materials to externalise their experiences of UTI symptoms.
This engagement turns representation into a dynamic, participatory
process in which perception and interpretation develop through material
interaction. Qualities such as texture, rigidity, or weight provoke
associations and gestures, enabling participants to express sensations
that may be difficult to articulate verbally. As they work with these
materials, participants reflect on their own experiences, compare
perspectives with others, and develop a shared language for discussing
symptoms.

This interpretive process is guided by the physical variables, which
offer a shared yet adaptable structure for interaction with materials.
Variables allow representations to move from individual perception to
collective understanding by providing common references that
participants can interpret, compare, and respond to. Through this
exchange, private and intimate experiences become contextualised forms
of knowledge that can support and enrich clinical dialogue.

The integration of data-probes and physical variables forms the basis of
a participatory workshop involving women with lived experience of UTIs
and healthcare professionals. The workshop explores how these tools
translate personal and subjective symptoms into communicable and
meaningful evidence. The next chapter presents the protocol and
materials of this workshop, showing how the methodology developed within
this framework operates both as a research tool and as an intervention
that supports more inclusive, reflective, and actionable forms of
healthcare knowledge.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
Workshops within design methodology are structured and facilitated
sessions in which participants take part in exploratory, reflective, or
generative activities that contribute to a design process. Their purpose
is not limited to producing solutions. They also operate as settings for
questioning assumptions, uncovering needs, and co-constructing meaning
through shared engagement. In this research, the workshop environment
introduces diverse stakeholders to the use of materials guided by
physical variables, creating the conditions for collecting and
communicating symptoms in ways that foreground embodied experience and
support collaborative understanding. The purpose of the activity is to
engage women experiencing intimate infections to improve their ability
to collect and share data. This initiative aims to enhance their
understanding of the disease, improve their communication skills, and
ultimately contribute to more accurate diagnoses. The research focuses
on UTIs with particular attention to recurrent episodes and chronic
conditions. UTI symptoms are explored in depth to better understand
their variability and impact over diagnosis and treatment, including
antibiotic prescription and consumption as aspects of the broader
experience of the disease.

The process of adopting materials to work on personal data aims to
support clearer communication of symptoms, while also helping to define
the structure and format through which personal data and narratives can
be shared with others involved and healthcare professionals. To
facilitate participation and promote data literacy, the activity
incorporates a variety of tools that guide and support participants
engagement, particularly to: (i) enhance their understanding of health
information, (ii) clarify and support the explanation of symptoms during
medical consultations, (iii) improve knowledge related to the disease.

The next section introduces the workshop protocol, outlining the
structure of the activity and showing how concepts developed in the
literature review are translated into practice. The protocol describes
the sequence of tasks and clarifies the role of materials and physical
variables throughout the session. An initial pilot workshop preceded the
full implementation of the protocol. This pilot tested the tasks and the
overall flow of the activity, identifying elements that required
adjustment. Insights from the pilot are discussed at the end of this
chapter, as they guided the development of the final version of the
format.

Following the pilot, each workshop iteration contributed further
refinements to the methodology. The specific conditions under which
these workshops took place, including participant characteristics and
contextual details, are presented in Chapter 4, which focuses on the
analysis of results. Observations and feedback from each session,
including medical experts’ evaluations of the approach, are examined in
Chapter 5 on methodological assessment. Chapter 6 then situates these
outcomes within the broader context of the research, providing the
discussion that connects empirical findings with the conceptual
contributions of the thesis.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
The workshop proposed for this research is designed to last
approximately 2.5 to 3 hours and involves a small group of participants
(5-8) working together in the same physical space. The primary focus is
on women, who represent the main target of this research. Participants
include individuals with lived experience of UTIs as well as
professionals with relevant expertise, such as doctors, nurses, and
pharmacists. In addition, caregivers and family members are also invited
to join the activity, given their potential role in supporting the
management and understanding of recurrent or chronic UTI experiences.
This diverse composition is intended to foster dialogue across personal
and clinical perspectives, particularly in relation to the broader
issues of diagnosis, treatment, and antibiotic resistance.

The research focuses on women because UTIs disproportionately affect
them, largely as a result of anatomical factors that increase
susceptibility. The literature (chapter 2) also shown that women are
frequently overlooked in the design of healthcare services and products,
and that data concerning women’s health is often interpreted within
male-dominated clinical and research environments. These conditions
limit attention to gender-specific concerns and contribute to persistent
gaps in how women’s experiences are understood and addressed. To
facilitate dialogue and create a setting in which participants feel as
comfortable as possible, the workshops bring together individuals with
lived experience of UTIs and healthcare experts who share a gender
identity. Forming groups composed of women with experience of the
condition supports a sense of familiarity and shared bodily
understanding, which can help reduce discomfort when discussing intimate
symptoms. Participation is voluntary, and activities take place in small
groups of approximately five people to cultivate an inclusive
environment in which each contribution can be voiced and acknowledged.
In line with the methodological orientation of the research, the
workshop format is implemented across multiple iterations, with
different participants involved in each session.

children.name: Step-by-step activity definition
children.content:
The following steps intend to introduce and explain the workshop
activity:

Step 0 — Before the workshop

Participants receive an onboarding email with brief information about
the research and an invitation to share experiences related to UTIs and,
if relevant, antibiotic resistance. The email includes the consent form
and information sheet, which participants are asked to return signed by
the day of the workshop. A Microsoft Form contains one open question
(“What is your experience of UTI and antibiotic resistance?”),
intentionally phrased to allow participants to share only what they feel
comfortable disclosing.

Step 1 - Arrival and introduction (workshop day)

Participants are welcomed into a room arranged with seats around a
central table. A slide presentation introduces the project and guides
them through the session.

Step 2 - Definition of “symptom” (10 minutes)

To open discussion, each participant writes a personal definition of
“symptom” on a card. Everyone then reads their definition aloud and
briefly introduces themselves, sharing names and reasons for taking
part.

Step 3 - Symptom identification (10 minutes)

Participants identify UTI symptoms they typically experience.
Pre-prepared labels with common symptoms extracted from the literature
help initiate the process.

Step 4 - Symptom relevance (20 minutes)

Participants collaboratively order the symptom labels by relevance.
Guiding questions include: what symptoms matter most in your experience?
And why are these symptoms important? Empty labels allow participants to
add missing symptoms. By the end of this phase, the group produces a
collectively ordered set of symptoms they consider characteristic of
infections such as cystitis.

Step 5 - Introducing the concept of “shaping” (5 minutes)

The research’s approach to representing symptoms through objects is
introduced using slides and case studies from data physicalization to
clarify what shaping entails.

Step 6 - Familiarisation with materials (10 minutes)

Participants explore the material units used in data-probes. Cubes,
spheres, and triangular prisms made of wood, polystyrene, and rubber
foam in different sizes are distributed on the table. Participants help
arrange these objects by matching them with cards indicating shape,
material, and size.

Step 7 - Introduction of physical variable labels (10 minutes)

Participants are introduced to labels describing physical variables such
as shape, colour, dimension, and weight, drawn from the literature.

Step 8 - Association of symptoms with physical variables (30 minutes)

Participants match the symptom labels defined earlier with labels
describing physical variables. Labels are designed as interlocking
puzzle pieces to support pairing. The aim is to create a shared
“vocabulary” that defines how symptoms can be represented through
material properties. Examples include associating “swollen stomach” with
“size” or “bloody urine” with “texture.” Empty labels can be added for
missing physical properties. Participants must explain and justify their
choices, ensuring the vocabulary reflects their perceptions and
interpretations.

Step 9 - Shaping the artefact (30 minutes)

Each participant individually selects, assembles, and modifies materials
to create an artefact representing their symptoms. Guiding questions
include: what shape do your symptoms evoke? What feeling does the
symptom provoke? Which object could express this feeling, and why?

This hands-on engagement encourages reflection and self-awareness as
participants translate their personal symptom stories into physical
form.

Step 10 - Reflection and presentation (30 minutes)

Participants present their artefacts, explaining material choices and
reflecting on their personal experiences of the condition. Discussion is
encouraged, allowing others to engage with the representations. Emphasis
is placed on explaining how specific materials relate to particular
sensations or experiences. This reflection supports greater
self-awareness and provides a socially acceptable way to express aspects
of the illness that are difficult to verbalise.

children.name: 3.3.2 Materials and components for the activity
Introduction
children.content:
Different tools have been designed to support the activities just
described. These include ice-breaking card, the labels of symptoms, the
data-probes material components to shape the artefacts, the labels of
the physical variables, and the assessment tablecloth. The method of
selection and realisation are described below.

children.name: Ice-breaking symptom definition card
children.content:
To open the activity, each participant receives a 20 × 10 cm paper card
and is asked to describe what a symptom is based on their personal
experience and feelings. The prompt on the card invites them to “imagine
explaining what a symptom is to a new friend who does not speak your
language well and is hearing this word for the first time”. This framing
encourages simple, direct descriptions and supports a comfortable start
to the conversation.

children.name: The labels of symptoms
The data-probes material kit
children.content:
The material kit provided for the shaping activity includes three basic
geometric forms, which are cube, sphere, and triangular prism, each
available in two sizes, labelled as small and large. These shapes are
made from three different materials: wood, polyester, and foam. This
combination offers participants a total of 18 unique options to choose
from. In addition, short and long wooden pegs are provided, along with
flexible transparent connectors, to support the assembly of multiple
units. Each shape features small holes on every face, allowing the pegs
to be inserted and the components to be joined together.

children.name: The labels of physical variables
children.content:
To provide participants with a set of physical features suitable for
representing and describing their symptoms, the research draws on the
list of variables proposed by Hornecker et al. (2023). Their work offers
one of the most extensive mappings of data physicalization practices
available, and it expands the conceptual foundations on which this study
builds. Their proposed vocabulary includes explicit variables, implicit
properties, and consequential aspects, capturing both tangible qualities
and perceptual dimensions of interaction that are particularly relevant
for communicating embodied experiences. For the purposes of this
workshop, however, only a curated subset of these variables is
introduced to participants. This selection responds to two
considerations. First, not all participants are expected to be familiar
with specialised material terminology or abstract categories such as
implicit or consequential aspects. Second, the workshop operates within
practical constraints of material availability, meaning that certain
variables identified by Hornecker et al. cannot be meaningfully
represented with the physical components used in the activity. The
following list therefore reflects a simplified and accessible adaptation
of Hornecker et al.’s broader classification, offering participants a
focused set of variables that supports meaningful, embodied
interpretation without requiring prior expertise.

- Position;

- Shape;

- Size;

- Colour;

- Orientation;

- Pattern/Texture;

- Fuzziness/Blurriness;

- Roughness;

- Viscosity;

- Weight;

- Timing;

- Movement/Motion;

- Opacity;

- 3S-Form/Contour;

- Brightness.

While the majority of them look self-explanatory, it is worth describing
what is meant by “3S-Form/Countor”. That is a tactile variable referring
to the felt form or contact contour of a physicalization, such as a
curvature (e.g., concave versus convex). Discussing the meaning of the
variable before starting to work with materials is incentivised as
contributing to the promotion of data literacy (one of the expected
outcomes of the workshop).

The symptoms and variables labels are intentionally designed in a
puzzle-like shape to intuitively suggest connection and combination
between elements, drawing inspiration from the Mix and Match Machine
Learning toolkit developed by Jansen and Colombo (2023), which similarly
employs interlocking components to support collaborative understanding
of machine learning (ML).

children.name: The assessment tablecloth
children.content:
Originally intended to protect the tables from dirt and potential damage
caused by assembling materials, each participant is provided with a
paper tablecloth. To make productive use of this element, and to
integrate feedback collection into the workshop flow, the tablecloths
are printed with a series of questions. These aim to investigate
participants’ engagement, identify which phase of the activity is most
difficult to understand or perform, assess comprehension of variables
and data-probes, and explore whether participants feel that some
materials is more suitable than others for representing symptoms.

Each question is accompanied by a set of options to collect feedback by
minimising the cognitive effort. While responses are optional, the
continuous presence of the tablecloths during the entire shaping phase
increases the likelihood that participants will take the time to
complete them and potentially also using the surface to jot down notes
or observations as needed.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
The workshop format is designed to generate a range of qualitative data types that emerge across different stages of the activity. Each task produces specific forms of material or verbal output, which together build a multi-layered dataset combining textual, visual, and embodied expressions of symptom experience. Table 1 summarises the data formats generated in each phase, the collection methods used, the actions required from participants, and the purpose of collecting each data type. The descriptions that follow provide a concise explanation of each category.
Data description Collection modality Collection support Data initial format Data format for analysis Action required to participant Purpose of collection
(A) Personal stories and experiences Individual (pre-workshop) Online form Written description Text Writing Initiate self-reflection and assess communication style
(B) Symptom definition Individual + group Paper cards + audio-recording Paper scan and audio-transcript Text Writing + verbal introduction Stimulate reflection, support group alignment
(C) Biographic information Individual Audio-recording Audio-transcript Text Oral self-introduction Contextualise participant profile, clarify motivations
(D) Symptoms identification Group Labels + audio-recording Pictures + Audio-transcript List of symptoms + text Selection, discussion, writing Identify key symptoms and support conversation
(E) Physical variables identification Group Labels + audio-recording Pictures + Audio-transcript List of variables + text Selection, discussion, writing Familiarise participants with material vocabulary
(F) Symptom-variable association Group Labels + audio-recording Pictures + Audio-transcript Table of associations + text Grouping labels, verbal dialogue Map physical qualities to symptom experiences
(G) Artefacts Individual 3D artefacts (data-probes) Pictures Image + List of components Selecting and assembling Elicit embodied symptom expression through material construction
(H) Presentation of artefacts Individual + group Audio-recording Audio-transcript Text Verbal presentation Analyse metaphor, vocabulary, and embodied narratives
Tab. 1 - Collection modalities, methods, participant actions, and purposes are summarized in the table below for each data type relevant to the study.

children.name: Personal story and experience of the disease
children.content:
Participants submit open-format written narratives prior to the activity
via a Microsoft online form. These unstructured text files offer direct
insight into their lived experiences and communication styles. Texts are
compiled into a single file for cross-reference with other datasets to
identify emerging patterns and correlations.

children.name: Symptom definitions
children.content:
Participants respond to a printed prompt on paper cards, using an open
format constrained only by a five-line space. These definitions are used
as an introduction occasion for individual presentations to the group.
Audio recordings of verbal presentations are transcribed and compared
with written input. Cards are scanned for storage purposes.

children.name: Biographic information
children.content:
Participants introduce themselves at the beginning of the workshop,
sharing their motivation for attending, relationship to the condition,
age group, and place of residence. These verbal introductions are
audio-recorded and later transcribed to capture contextual insights.
Participant profiles are used to inform interpretation of other data
types, enabling cross-analysis by role, experience, and demographic
context. Statements are categorised to identify typologies (e.g.,
patient, caregiver, health professional), which support comparative and
intersectional readings across workshop outputs.

children.name: Symptoms identification
children.content:
Participants select and organize symptom labels collectively. Layouts
(typically hierarchical) are documented via sequential photography. The
final configuration, along with any added or discarded symptoms, informs
frequency analysis and relevance mapping. Conversations are transcribed
to capture reasoning behind choices and enrich the information on
selection.

children.name: Physical variables identification
children.content:
This step replicates symptom identification but centres on material
properties. Participants engage with predefined variable labels.
Language translation may be required for participants who are not native
speakers. The way participants describe and interpret variables during
translation also provides valuable insights into their conceptual
understanding. Photographs document how participants arrange the labels,
while audio recordings capture their reasoning, personal
interpretations, and tactile impressions that inform and justify those
choices.

children.name: Symptom-variable association
children.content:
Labels are physically grouped to reflect perceived connections. Spatial
arrangements are photographed and recorded in structured spreadsheets to
track co-occurrence patterns. Audio transcripts offer critical insight
into participant rationale and interpretive frameworks.

children.name: Artefacts
children.content:
Participants construct 3D artefacts using modular material units. Each
artefact is photographed from optimal angles to document components. A
bill of materials complements each image, aiding in comparative
analysis. Probes are later disassembled to preserve materials for future
sessions.

children.name: Presentation of artefacts
children.content:
Participants verbally present their artefacts, linking them to personal
health experiences. Audio recordings are transcribed for thematic
analysis. Language used to describe components is mapped back to
physical features to explore how embodiment and metaphor facilitate
symptom expression.

Based on the varied formats and purposes of the collected data, the aim
of the next chapter is to outline an analytical method capable of
operating across these different modalities.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
Originally, cultural probes were not designed to be analysed or to
extract specific information. Instead, insights were drawn from what the
materials allowed the researcher to observe and understand (Gaver et
al., 1999). Similarly, data physicalizations are generally not created
to be decoded in detail, as their purpose is to communicate data through
form, rather than to support precise interpretation or retrieval of
specific values.

However, the role assigned to data-probes in this research differs from
the methods it relies on and therefore requires a defined structure for
analysing the outcomes they generate. Establishing this structure first
requires clarifying the function that data assumes within the study and
how the materials collected contribute to knowledge production, which
are:

1.  Expanding the medical knowledge related to a specific disease and
    condition (UTIs);

2.  Improving the use of physicality in participatory environments to
    support self-awareness and communication of intimate and
    health-related conditions.

The study primarily generates qualitative data. The process begins with
participants’ written stories, continues through structured and
unstructured discussions during the workshop, and concludes with spoken
descriptions of the artefacts created. Each workshop produces a full
audio recording of group interaction, later transcribed for analysis.
Written notes complement the transcripts by capturing contextual cues
and non-verbal aspects of interaction. Printed cards, labels, and other
support materials are also analysed, as they contribute to understanding
the interpretive strategies used during the activities.

Analysis of the physical artefacts requires dedicated methods. Each
object is photographed from multiple angles and accompanied by a
structured description detailing its form, arrangement, and material
components. These descriptions allow comparison across artefacts and
support integration with written and spoken narratives. Artefact
documentation provides an essential complement to transcripts, enabling
the identification of correspondences between verbal descriptions,
material choices, and embodied interpretations of symptoms.

Different origins, types and formats of data, but also variated needs of
comparing and combining different results, orient this research to
consider mixed methods (Poth, 2023) and multimethod research
(Muratovski, 2022) for the analysis. The following chapters present the
data analysis strategies selected to address the two purposes outlined
above (A; B). Thematic analysis is applied to written narratives,
transcripts, and spoken descriptions to identify patterns in how
participants articulate symptoms and engage with materials.
Compositional interpretation is used to examine the artefacts, focusing
on how their material configurations express experiential meaning and
how these meanings connect to participants’ accounts.

Together, these approaches support a structured examination of how
embodied experiences of UTIs are expressed, shared, and transformed
through material engagement within the workshop setting.

children.name: Thematic analysis
children.content:
Thematic analysis is considered for this project as the primary method
for interpreting the qualitative data collected during the workshop
sessions. To define and structure this process, the foundational
framework developed by Braun and Clarke (2006, 2013) is taken as the
main reference. Their model offers a flexible, systematic approach to
identifying and analysing recurring patterns within qualitative data,
making it particularly suitable for design research contexts that
involve complex, subjective, and open-ended participant contributions.

Additional references were consulted to better contextualise the
application of thematic analysis within this research. Maguire and
Delahunt (2017) provided a step-by-step guide that clarified the
practical implementation of the method. Saldaña (2013) contributed a
detailed account of coding practices, offering guidance on how coding
decisions influence theme development. Nowell et al. (2017) were
examined to support methodological rigour, with particular attention to
criteria for transparency, consistency, and trustworthiness.
Furthermore, the work of Karlsen et al. (2017) was reviewed as a
relevant example of thematic analysis applied to qualitative data within
a healthcare setting.

Central to thematic analysis is the identification of themes, defined as
patterns that capture something important about the data in relation to
the research questions. A theme represents a level of patterned meaning
or response within the dataset and is not simply a repeated word or
phrase but an interpretative structure that organises insights around
shared concepts or issues. Themes can be identified in two primary ways.
An inductive or data-driven approach builds themes directly from the raw
material without pre-existing categories, as exemplified by Frith and
Gleeson (2004). Conversely, a deductive or theory-driven approach
applies pre-defined concepts or analytical lenses to guide the coding
and theme development.

Another key distinction involves the level of theme identification. At
the semantic level, the analysis focuses on the surface meaning of the
data. In this case, the researcher organises and summarises what
participants have said, progressing from simple description to
interpretation of patterns in their explicit content. In contrast,
latent theme identification involves a deeper, interpretative
engagement. In this case, the analysis moves beyond what is explicitly
stated to uncover the underlying assumptions, conceptualisations, or
ideologies that may shape the data.

Based on the literature reviewed on thematic analysis, this research
adopts a terminology that ensures clarity and consistency throughout the
analytical process. The data corpus refers to the full body of
qualitative material collected during the project, while the data set
indicates the specific portion of the corpus selected for thematic
analysis. Within this data set, data extracts are defined as individual
segments that have been coded as meaningful in relation to the research
focus. The analysis involves a continuous movement between the entire
data set, the coded extracts, and the emerging interpretation. Rather
than being treated as a separate phase, writing forms an integral part
of the analytical process, supporting the gradual development of
descriptive accounts and the refinement of themes. This iterative
engagement with the material allows for the progressive clarification of
patterns and relationships, leading to a coherent thematic structure.

The approach adopted for this project is primarily based on Braun and
Clarke (2006), with adjustments made in response to the nature of the
data. Both semantic and latent themes were identified, depending on the
characteristics of each dataset and the nature of the workshop
activities. Thematic analysis is applied here as a method that allows
for a balance between essentialist readings of participants’ accounts
and more interpretative, constructionist insights into how meaning is
shaped through material and discursive practices.

children.name: Compositional interpretation
children.content:
To complement the thematic analysis of written and verbal data,
compositional interpretation is adopted to examine the visual and
material artefacts created by participants during the workshop sessions.
Coined by Rose (2001), the term "compositional interpretation" refers to
a formalist method for analysing visual material by focusing on its
internal organisation and aesthetic features. This approach originates
in art historical practices, particularly those associated with the
analysis of paintings, and is rooted in Irit Rogoff’s notion of “the
good eye.” But, while “the good eye” assumes an evaluative stance based
on the analyst’s prior knowledge and expertise, compositional
interpretation places emphasis on the visual qualities of the object
itself, seeking to provide a structured and descriptive reading of form,
colour, spatial arrangement, and visual effect, that are independent of
subjective judgement or external context.

In this research, compositional interpretation is adapted to the
analysis of three-dimensional artefacts produced during data-probe
activities. Although originally developed for two-dimensional imagery,
the method translates effectively to physical objects, offering a
systematic structure for documenting their formal and material
characteristics. This adaptation is essential, as the artefacts stand as
independent data items that express embodied experiences through
material configuration. A descriptive method is therefore needed to
capture their visual and tactile features with precision and
consistency.

The artefacts produced during the workshop play a dual role within the
methodology. On one hand, they operate as conversational mediators,
helping participants articulate sensations, reflect on their
experiences, and communicate aspects of UTIs that are difficult to
express verbally. On the other hand, they function as analytical objects
in their own right. Their shapes, textures, arrangements, and material
combinations provide concrete evidence of how participants understand,
conceptualise, and externalise their symptoms. This duality raises
specific analytical questions: how should the artefact be read
independently from its verbal explanation? What constitutes relevant
descriptive information? How can material decisions be examined without
imposing subjective assumptions?

To address these questions, compositional interpretation is used to
produce a written description of each artefact that focuses strictly on
formal qualities: shape, spatial organisation, material composition,
surface treatment, colour, and any visible modifications. This
documentation is followed by a structured listing of the components used
in its construction. Through this detailed descriptive layer, each
artefact is established as a distinct data source, enabling comparisons
across workshop iterations and supporting the integration of material
evidence with verbal accounts.

Once this descriptive foundation is established, the artefact is
compared with the participant’s spoken and written explanations through
thematic analysis. This comparison highlights how material forms may
reinforce, complicate, or diverge from the verbal account of symptoms.
Beginning with compositional analysis ensures that interpretations
remain grounded in what is materially and visually present, avoiding
premature assumptions or over-reliance on narrative data.

This method is meant to prevent the artefacts from being reduced to
illustrations of participants’ stories. Instead, they are analysed as
autonomous outputs that reflect experiential knowledge shaped through
material engagement. Compositional interpretation therefore acts both as
a descriptive tool and as an analytical bridge, connecting the sensory
qualities of material form with the subjective narratives through which
participants make sense of their symptoms.

children.name: 3.3.5 Ethics and approval
children.content:
Ethical considerations play a central role in this research, as the data
collected involve personal experiences and bodily information related to
health conditions. Participants are invited to reflect on and share
aspects of their physical symptoms, emotional states, and experiences of
diseases. Given the sensitive and intimate nature of these
contributions, particular attention is paid to informed consent,
voluntary participation, data protection, and the creation of a safe and
respectful environment throughout all phases of the study.

This research receives full ethical approval from Brunel University
London’s College of Engineering, Design and Physical Sciences Research
Ethics Committee (reference number: 44341-MHR-Oct/2023- 47640-2). Other
approvals are obtained for intermediary stages and activities of the
research. All the approvals can be found in the Appendix of this thesis.

In addition to the approval granted by Brunel University, separate
ethics approvals are granted from the institutions where local
iterations of the workshop were hosted. Specifically:

- SUPSI University (Switzerland), which hosted the first and third
  workshop sessions.

- University of Bern (Switzerland), where a session was conducted at the
  invitation of Dr. Paola Pierri, coordinator of the Social Design
  course.

Participants are recruited as volunteers based on their lived experience
or professional knowledge of UTIs. All participants receive an
information sheet detailing the purpose, structure, and scope of the
study. Informed consent is collected prior to participation.
Participants were also informed, both in writing and verbally at the
beginning of each session, that their involvement was voluntary and that
they were free to withdraw at any point, without the need to give a
reason.

The workshop format is designed to foster open participation without
placing pressure on participants to speak or disclose sensitive
information. For this reason, no turns of speech or prescribed
intervention modalities are organised. As such, it is possible for
participants to take part in the workshop without contributing verbally,
if they chose to remain silent. The physical and creative components of
the workshop offer alternative means of engagement, making participation
accessible at different levels of comfort and expression.

At the end of each session, participants are invited to provide optional
feedback and were encouraged to contact the research team directly if
they wished to discuss any matters in private, including topics they did
not feel comfortable addressing in the group setting. This post-session
opportunity ensures that participants retain full control over how and
when they share aspects of their experiences.

Together, these measures form the ethical strategy adopted in this
research, which prioritises participant autonomy, confidentiality, and
emotional safety, and ensures that embodied and intimate accounts of
health are handled with care and respect across all stages of the study.

children.name: 3.3.6 Data collection and management
children.content:
At the beginning of each session, participants are reminded that the
conversation will be audio-recorded. A non-invasive recording device is
placed at the centre of the table. Audio recording serves as the primary
method for capturing the conversation generated during the workshop and
is considered the main source of data for this research. These
recordings are essential for supporting the understanding of contextual
nuances and participant interactions during analysis.

Participants provide consent to be photographed as part of the consent
form, with the option to take part in the activity without being
photographed. When a participant opts out, care is taken to avoid
capturing their image. Any photographs in which participants are visible
are anonymised to ensure privacy and are used exclusively for research
purposes.

All audio recordings, transcriptions, and visual or written materials
produced during the workshops are stored securely in accordance with
Brunel University’s data management policy. Recordings are kept on a
password-protected network server and will be deleted upon completion of
the research. No identifiable information is included in the recordings,
and all personal data are anonymised during transcription to ensure
confidentiality. Access to raw data is restricted to myself and my
supervisors. When possible, field notes are taken during the sessions,
depending on my availability as both facilitator and researcher.

children.name: 3.3.7 My role, as the researcher and facilitator
children.content:
The workshop is the core of the methodology of my PhD research. Based on
a preliminary review of the literature, I designed the structure of the
workshop and developed the materials used during the sessions. I also
took on the role of facilitator, guiding the activities, introducing
each phase of the workshop, and doing my best to create a safe and
welcoming environment where participants felt comfortable enough to take
part and share intimate conditions.

Throughout the sessions, I paid close attention to maintaining a
balanced and inclusive atmosphere. I actively worked to prevent any
individual from dominating the discussion and tried to ensure that no
participant felt pressured to speak or share more than they wished. My
aim was to encourage open dialogue while respecting each participant’s
personal boundaries and pace of engagement.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
The assessment method developed for this research aligns with the dual
purpose established for data collection: (A) contributing to medical
knowledge related to UTIs, and (B) improving the use of physicality in
participatory environments to support self-awareness and the
communication of intimate or health-related conditions. The evaluation
therefore considers both the content generated through the workshop (A)
and the methodological performance of the format (B). On one hand, the
assessment examines whether the workshop enables the emergence of
medically relevant insights from participants. On the other, it aims to
refine the methodological use of physicalization as a tool for
qualitative research and design-based enquiry.

Given this dual intent, the assessment is structured around two
complementary approaches. In practice, however, these dimensions are
closely intertwined as they address a single, unified activity, and the
data produced during the workshops frequently serve both purposes. As a
result, findings cannot always be cleanly separated, and the assessment
embraces this overlap as a characteristic of the method.

children.name: (A) Assessing the content: semi-structured interview to medical experts
children.content:
To address the first objective, the research adopts a targeted expert
validation process. Selected medical professionals are invited to review
initial results from the workshops, including original materials used in
the analysis such as written narratives, artefact descriptions, and
conversation transcripts. Experts are asked to comment on the clarity,
relevance, and clinical value of the health-related information that
emerges. This feedback serves to verify the medical significance of the
insights collected and to clarify the potential of the workshop format
to contribute to broader medical and healthcare discussions. The
assessment therefore aims to explore the value of personal narratives
and embodied representations as supplementary forms of knowledge within
patient-centred research.

For this purpose, semi-structured interviews were conducted with medical
professionals who have expertise in UTIs. The involvement of experts had
two primary goals: first, to determine whether new or tacit knowledge
about UTIs emerges during the workshops; and second, to evaluate whether
participants use alternative terms or communication modalities when
describing symptoms and experiences of the disease. Healthcare
professionals identified in earlier phases of the research were
contacted via email and invited to participate. Once they confirmed
their interest, each expert received a personalised document containing
a selection of workshop results, including transcript excerpts,
summaries of participant contributions, and descriptions of artefacts.
Experts were asked to read the material, add written comments, and
reflect on both the clinical relevance and the linguistic or narrative
characteristics of the content.

Each version of the analysis was shared individually so experts could
comment freely and without influence from others. Following this review,
an online semi-structured interview was conducted to explore their
reflections in greater depth. Access to the documents was granted only
after experts had confirmed participation and scheduled the interview.
Materials were shared via private email to ensure confidentiality.

Ethics approval for this activity was obtained from Brunel University's
Research Ethics Committee (Reference: 49695-LR-Sep/2024-52885-2).
Findings from these interviews are presented in the chapter 5.

children.name: (B) Assessing the methodology: feedback reiteration
children.content:
To address the second objective, the workshop methodology is evaluated
through an iterative and practice-based approach consistent with design
research principles. Rather than relying on a fixed set of criteria, the
assessment is embedded within the activity itself. Each session
functions simultaneously as a moment of data generation and as a
methodological experiment, revealing how the structure, materials, and
facilitation style could be refined.

This approach draws on design research traditions in which making,
testing, and reflection are interdependent (Koskinen et al., 2011).
Assessment therefore takes place in situ, through direct engagement with
participants and with the unfolding activity, aligning with established
models of reflective practice (Schön, 1983) and iterative prototyping
(Zimmerman et al., 2007). Feedback is gathered through observation,
post-session reflection, and participant comments, enabling continuous
adjustments to the workshop format in terms of clarity, timing, level of
engagement, and the expressive potential of the materials.

The protocol presented in this chapter reflects the final iteration,
consolidated after multiple rounds of refinement. Changes incorporated
into this version emerge from practical constraints, participant
feedback, and observations of how effectively the physicalization
process supports expression and self-awareness. The following paragraphs
outline the specific strategies used for this assessment.

A first source of feedback comes from participant responses collected
during and after the sessions. One of the main tools for this purpose is
the paper tablecloths described earlier among the material components.
These surfaces include printed questions designed to assess engagement,
to explore how participants understand the role of variables and
data-probes, and to gather impressions about whether alternative
materials might be more suitable for representing symptoms.

While the tablecloths offer a structured channel for feedback,
participants are also encouraged to provide open-ended reflections at
the end of the workshop. These comments often address aspects not
captured by the predefined questions, particularly regarding the
usefulness and accessibility of the materials.

Additionally, the written descriptions submitted before the workshop are
compared with the final descriptions of the artefacts produced during
the session. This comparison aims to identify changes in vocabulary,
level of detail, and ways of framing or articulating symptoms. Observing
these shifts supports an evaluation of how the workshop format may
influence participants' perception and communication of their condition.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
The first workshop session plays a foundational role in refining the
protocol presented in this chapter. As the initial enactment of the
method, the pilot functions both as a test of the workshop structure and
as an opportunity to translate the theoretical foundations of the
research into practice. Feedback from participants, together with
insights gathered through the expert interview, informs several
adjustments to the materials, facilitation strategy, and organisation of
tasks. These changes shape the final protocol and prepare the ground for
the analysis of results presented in Chapter 4.

children.name: 3.4.1 Purpose of the pilot
children.content:
The pilot workshop is conducted to identify aspects of the activity that
require clarification, restructuring, or material adaptation. This
initial activity aim is to evaluate how participants interact with the
tasks, how the materials support or constrain expression, and how the
facilitation strategy can better accommodate both lay participants and
medical experts. The feedback presented below is organised around the
methodological elements that the pilot helped to refine.

children.name: Protocol adjustments
children.content:
Participants were originally asked to submit a written description of
their experience before the session by responding to an online form. Not
all participants completed this step. To ensure consistent data
collection across sessions, the written narrative task was incorporated
directly into the workshop. Time was allocated at the beginning of the
activity for participants to write their narratives on a printed card,
ensuring that every participant contributed a comparable written
account.

children.name: Material availability and organisation
children.content:
The material assortment made available during the pilot workshop
included a diverse selection of geometric units designed to offer
participants multiple tactile and expressive possibilities. The kit
comprised cubes made of wood, polystyrene, and foam rubber, each
available in three size ranges, which are small (2–4 cm), medium (4–6
cm), and large (6–10 cm). A corresponding set of spheres was provided in
the same size gradations and produced in wood, polystyrene, and steel.
Additional shapes included wooden cylinders and triangular prisms in
polystyrene and foam rubber. These components were arranged on a printed
paper grid intended to help participants navigate the options.

During the pilot, however, this organisational system generated
confusion. Because not all shape–material–size combinations existed, the
incomplete grid suggested a structure that the material kit could not
fully support. Participants occasionally struggled to locate specific
units, and the grid implicitly framed the materials in ways that did not
reflect the openness of the activity. In response, later sessions
replaced the grid with labelled tags naming each material unit, such as
“Small wooden cube” or “Large foam sphere.” Participants were asked to
place the materials next to the corresponding tags at the beginning of
the session, creating an initial familiarisation step that supported
orientation and encouraged agency during shaping.

The expert who attended the pilot echoed these concerns. She appreciated
the tactile and expressive qualities of the materials but observed that
the structured A0 grid unintentionally acted as an interpretative frame.
For example, participants might infer that larger shapes represent more
severe symptoms. This observation aligned with participants’ own remarks
about the difficulty of navigating the grid. The expert therefore
recommended presenting materials in a more randomised and unstructured
manner to avoid bias and to preserve the personal, exploratory nature of
the activity. She further suggested broadening the palette of materials
by including paper, fabric, colour, or digital components, which could
expand expressive possibilities and reduce the implicit influence of the
grid.

children.name: Label redesign
children.content:
Participants reported that the laser-cut wooden labels used to describe
material properties were difficult to handle because of their size,
rigidity, and polished surface. Their smooth finish reduced tactile
engagement, and their dimensions (13.5 × 7 cm) made them cumbersome
during the activity. In response to this feedback, the labels were
redesigned as smaller paper tags (6 × 4 cm), which proved more flexible,
approachable, and easier to manipulate. This redesign was applied both
to the general descriptive labels and to those representing the physical
variables, ensuring greater comfort and accessibility across all stages
of the workshop.

children.name: Capturing limitations
children.content:
Post-it notes were introduced to give participants a way to express
preferences for materials not included in the kit which were otherwise
not properly recorded. This helped clarify that the purpose of the
workshop was not to perfect the kit, but to observe how physical
variables support expression. Despite constraints, participants
demonstrated strong and meaningful engagement, confirming the adequacy
of the available materials.

children.name: Adjustments to facilitation and expert involvement
children.content:
During the pilot, medical professionals were originally asked to
participate in the same way as other participants. This approach proved
unsuitable, as clinical expertise does not necessarily correspond to
personal experience of UTIs. To resolve this, a set of targeted
questions was prepared specifically for medical experts. These questions
were asked during moments when participants were engaged in individual
tasks, enabling experts to contribute reflections without disrupting or
influencing the group dynamic. This strategy avoided the need for
additional sessions while generating valuable insights during the
workshop itself.

children.name: The pilot workshop includes the participation of a healthcare professional based in Switzerland whose profile offers a relevant but distinct perspective within the group. She has been practising as a nurse for six years and has recently completed a master’s degree in nursing sciences. Her professional background includes work in gynaecology clinics, where she supported expectant mothers and young women, giving her a solid foundation in women’s health. She currently works in a care home for older adults, where urinary tract infections are a frequent clinical concern that she encounters almost daily. Although she has not personally experienced UTIs, she brings valuable professional insight through her ongoing clinical practice, answering the following questions.
children.content:
- To clarify her role in the workshop and refine expert involvement, a
  forty-five minute online semi-structured interview is conducted after
  the session. What did work? / What did not work?

- What phase was most difficult to understand? / What phase was most
  difficult to perform?

- What goal was best reached, in your opinion?

- What is the main achievement?

- Did you feel engaged?

- What material would you have liked to have instead of the one
  provided?

- Was the vocabulary adopted during the activity too difficult?

- Did you encounter difficulties in interacting with other participants?

- Would you like to have another expert on the table with you?

- Did you feel useful during the activity? Try to define your role
  within the activity.

During this conversation, she expresses a positive evaluation of the
method, noting the usefulness of material prompts for externalising
personal experiences of illness and linking the approach to storytelling
practices commonly employed in nursing education. She also identifies
the final model-making activity as a meaningful moment of synthesis for
participants. The interview generates several themes concerning the
usefulness of the activity, the clarity of its phases, and the relevance
of the method for healthcare contexts. These themes are presented below,
together with the adjustments introduced in response.

children.name: Need for clarity in diagnosis and scope
children.content:
The expert noted that some participants described symptoms more aligned
with candidiasis than with UTIs. To prevent confusion, she recommended
clearly defining UTIs and their symptoms during recruitment and at the
start of the workshop, distinguishing UTIs from other conditions such as
candidiasis or vulvodynia, and providing a brief medically grounded
overview of UTIs. Similarly, participants’ feedback also indicated a
need for clearer framing of the condition.

children.name: Distinguishing signs from symptoms
children.content:
The expert emphasised the importance of distinguishing between signs,
which are clinically observable, and symptoms, which refer to subjective
experiences. Introducing this distinction through short explanations or
visual cards could help participants describe their perceptions with
greater precision and support collaboration with healthcare
professionals. Taking this feedback into account, the thesis expands the
literature review on this topic and clarifies how the methodology
engages with embodied perception. This distinction becomes a useful
conceptual anchor for framing the role of materials in the workshop,
showing how participants interpret and externalise subjective sensations
through physical variables.

children.name: Reordering workshop phases
children.content:
The expert recommended inverting the sequence of activities to support
more personal and less peer-influenced expression. Beginning with
individual exploration of materials enables participants to form
intuitive, embodied associations before encountering verbal prompts or
group input. Early exposure to others’ interpretations can
unintentionally narrow expressive possibilities or discourage intimate
reflections. The revised methodology therefore introduces a preliminary
phase of independent material engagement, followed by the presentation
of labels or prompts, and concludes with collective discussion. This
adjustment strengthens the alignment between the method and its aim of
eliciting authentic, experience-based representations of symptoms.

children.name: Clarifying the expert’s role
children.content:
The medical figure expressed concern about being the only clinician in a
group of patients, as participants occasionally turned to her for
medical guidance. She recommended either involving multiple experts or
assigning them the role of observers or facilitators rather than
co-participants. She also noted that participants’ questions stemmed
from genuine interest rather than fear, suggesting that expert presence
is valuable when roles are clearly communicated.

The feedback discussed above was particularly useful for redefining key
aspects of the activity and improving the methodology described in this
chapter. However, other workshop sessions also generated feedback,
which, although more limited in scope, contributed to further
refinements. These later insights are presented in the analysis of
results (chapter 4), as they emerged directly from the activity itself
and are therefore considered part of the data. This reflects the
iterative nature of the process on which this methodology is built.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
Defining the methodology of this work has been an iterative process. The
initial design of the activity provided a starting structure for
collecting data on symptom expression, yet the method was ultimately
refined through the insights generated during its own implementation.
The pilot workshop played a particularly influential role in shaping the
protocol. Feedback from participants and from the medical expert
attending the session informed several key adjustments to the structure,
materials, and facilitation strategy. Her observations helped clarify
the positioning of experts within the activity, the need for a clearer
framing of symptoms and related conditions, and the importance of
ensuring that material components support rather than constrain personal
expression.

While the pilot contributed substantially to the definition of the final
protocol, later workshop sessions also generated feedback. These
contributions were more limited in scope but remained valuable for
fine-tuning specific aspects of the format. Because these insights
emerged directly from participants’ real-time interaction with the
refined method, they are treated as part of the empirical data and
discussed within the analysis of results in Chapter 4. Together, the
pilot and subsequent iterations illustrate how the methodology evolves
in practice, with each session contributing to a clearer articulation of
the workshop’s structure and objectives.

The activity presented here therefore represents one possible
configuration among many that could be developed from the literature and
from the challenges identified throughout the project. To support future
research and guide researchers interested in applying or adapting this
approach, the following section outlines its current limitations and
offers considerations for further development.

children.name: 3.5.1 Limitations
children.content:
While this research adopts a rigorous and transparent methodology
grounded in design research and qualitative enquiry, several limitations
must be acknowledged. First, the inherently interpretative nature of
both thematic analysis and compositional interpretation introduces a
degree of subjectivity, as meaning and pattern recognition depend on the
researcher’s perspective. Although reflexivity and documentation of
methodological decisions are maintained throughout, the absence of
multiple coders or participant validation limits the intersubjective
reliability of the findings. This limitation is further reinforced by
the central role of the researcher in both facilitating and adapting the
workshop sessions. The success of the format thus partly depends on
tacit knowledge and contextual sensitivity, which challenges its
reproducibility and scalability in other settings or by other
practitioners.

Second, the iterative design and embedded assessment approach, while
suitable for experimental and participatory formats makes cross-session
comparison more complex. The methodological structure prioritises
process and insights over replicability, which aligns with the research
intention but constrains broader application.

The physical kit also introduces certain limitations. Constraints in
material diversity and the structural rigidity of some components may
have restricted expressive possibilities for some participants or
required a degree of manual dexterity that not everyone possesses.
Although the kit is intentionally designed to minimise the influence of
manual skill on both process and outcome, individual backgrounds and
levels of familiarity with making can still shape how comfortably
participants work with the materials. In some cases, attention to
aesthetic qualities may overshadow the focus on embodied experience,
which can reduce the clarity or validity of the resulting artefact as a
representation of symptoms.

Evaluating the impact and success of a collaborative, open-ended
methodology such as the one developed in this research also presents
specific limitations. As Shadlyn et al. (2022) note, assessing processes
grounded in participant expression and co-creation is intrinsically
complex, particularly when outcomes are non-standardised,
context-specific, and shaped by individual interpretation. This
challenge is amplified when working with qualitative data, where value
lies not in measurable outputs but in the depth and resonance of the
insights generated. Conventional academic indicators, such as
publications or funding metrics, therefore offer only a partial measure
of success.

Within design-led participatory research, alternative forms of
evaluation become essential. The extent to which the work is legible,
relevant, and meaningful to individuals or communities who experience
similar challenges becomes a key indicator of its contribution.
Engagement in related initiatives, such as workshops, exhibitions,
symposia, or public presentations, also plays a role by providing
opportunities for the work to be shared, questioned, and collaboratively
refined. These forms of evaluation remain less formalised than
traditional indicators yet align more closely with the aims of
participatory methodologies, which privilege dialogue, reflection, and
contextual knowledge.

The integration of expert commentary and real-time methodological
adjustments during the early phases of the project demonstrates how
assessment in this research is understood not as a single conclusive act
but as a continuous process of iteration. The feedback of medical
professionals is particularly valuable in strengthening the workshop
content and clarifying its clinical relevance. At the same time, the
involvement of experts introduces structural challenges. Recruiting
clinicians who are both qualified and available to participate proves as
difficult as involving participants with lived experience. The reliance
on voluntary engagement reflects a broader limitation within
participatory and co-creative research, where the ambition for inclusive
involvement must be balanced with the practical difficulty of
coordinating schedules, securing commitment, and ensuring availability.
The gap between methodological ideals and the logistical realities of
collaboration therefore remains an inherent constraint.

Recognising these limitations is essential for situating the scope of
this work. They highlight the contextual nature of the methodology, the
influence of facilitation and participation dynamics, and the challenges
of evaluating open-ended forms of knowledge production. At the same
time, they point to valuable directions for further refinement, ensuring
that future developments build on a clear understanding of the
constraints involved in field-based participatory research.

children.name: 3.5.2 Future considerations
children.content:
Future refinements focus on increasing the adaptability, clarity, and
impact of the methodology. A first direction concerns the development of
a more formal assessment framework that distinguishes between evaluating
the activity’s ability to elicit health-related insights and its
capacity to foster self-awareness and communication through
physicalization. Criteria such as expressiveness, engagement, clarity of
materials, and expert validation could support this distinction.

Strengthening the robustness of data interpretation may also involve
participatory or collaborative coding approaches, allowing participants
or co-researchers to contribute to the analytical phase. The material
kit, originally designed around simple and reproducible geometric units,
has proven effective through iterative testing, yet it remains open to
further refinement. Future versions may explore expanded textures,
colours, or digital components to broaden expressive possibilities
without compromising accessibility or the open-ended nature of the task.
Additional forms of engagement, such as follow-up interviews or
longitudinal reflections, could provide insight into the sustained
influence of the workshop on participants’ understanding and
communication of their symptoms.

Finally, the role of technology offers potential avenues for
development. Although the method has centred on physical materials and
embodied interaction, digital tools may enhance documentation,
interaction, remote participation, or data management in future
iterations. Such integration would require a reassessment of the
methodological framework, as digital mediation would influence both the
nature of the data and the forms of participant engagement.

Building on the methodology outlined in this chapter, the next chapter
presents the analysis of the results and the types of knowledge this
approach makes possible, together with contextual details from each
workshop session.
